title: Curating and Analyzing Oral History Collections
segmentation: My name is caught parking.

I hear from prior University building I'm a historian with very limited knowledge about linguistic methods or terminology, but due to a number of workshops that we did with Claren colleagues about oral history resources, I have the feeling that our data might be interesting for some of your research and also that the methods of linguists and declaring tools.
Might be helpful for historiographical questions.
So.
I'd start with brief some ideas about what is what are oral history collections?
My biographical interviews usually 2 three or more hours.
Length recorded often at the home of the narrators.
Their audiovisual narrative data.
Either with tape cassette recording now with digital records, often also video, but in very different qualities depending on the project on the collection.
They're like results of a dialogue between an interviewer and an aerator, but it's not a journalistic question.

For example, survivors of the Holocaust of the Second World War, forced laborers, but also oral history, deals with many other topics as well.
So it's just a person tells his life story and this is not just data for research, so there is a.
The difference there?
The interviewing method methods are pretty much informed by qualitative Social Research, so one could call these collections of these archives of oral history interviews, samples of qualitative data.

We also think of it like editorial projects, thinking of additions of manuscripts or other written historical sources, and we think that some of our work is similar to that, and we might also learn from them, like when they're using text encoding initiative and another format.
Of course, and that's why I'm here.
It's spoken language.
It's large corpora of spoken language, although the digital but not really standardized in a way that you and we would like them to be.
And the part of cultural heritage of public history.
It's also the different projects that we were working with were funded from public, non research non academic.
Foundations etc.
And so the idea of presenting the testimonies of survivors has also something to do with with dignity, with respect, which is maybe not a pure scholarly approach.
Sometimes so.

With the Visual History Archive, the Shore Foundation and then a number of other archives then used one which went online this April is the memories of the occupation in Greece.
Collection I don't go into the details about all these collections, but just to give you an idea there, sure foundations visual history Archive has about 53,000 video interviews.
We did transcribe 900 German language interviews.
I'm going to talk a little bit more about the second archive about forced labor during the Second World War and just you see that these are pretty large corpora with.

In other's, like the the refugee voices, British Jewish Collection of 150 video interviews about refugees from Nazi regime to Great Britain, we just integrated them into the library catalog and make them accessible and didn't do anymore work with that.

Talk a little bit more about the project forced Labor 1935, nineteen, 45.
A collection of almost 600 life story interviews put together and put online to commemorate about 20 million people that were forced to work for Nazi Germany during the Second World War.
From all the occupied countries in Europe.
So this collection was the interviews were conducted in 2000 five 2006.
An average length of 3 1/2 hours in 25 different languages, which certain focus in Russian, Polish and Czech.
Because that's where the countries where most of the first laborers were brought from to Germany.
We have different groups of persecuted people talking in these collections.
We did about 400.
So all the interviews are transcribed manually and about 400 of them were translated into German.
All the transcripts and translations have timecode, so they are connected to the audio video files and there are additional material, photos, documents, short biographies, etc.
So this was a large.
Project mainly with manual work supported by web based platform, but starting with the digitization of the tapes.
Lecturing of the transcript, the inserting of time codes for in the alignment with the audio or video, the translation, then indexation.
Maybe that's something that linguists would call annotation sociologists would call it coding.
Librarians colored.
Keywords, whatever.

Combining that into controlled vocabularies.
We created table of contents to make this long.
Three hours interviews, that's like 80 pages of text.
Bit more navigable for the researcher.
Then also worked with the accompanying material, photos, private documents etc.
And put up the whole thing in an online archival platform which is available in German, English in Russian.
You can access it online.
But you need registration we.
Do that because it's very long personal narrations and we want to take a bit of a control.
Who uses this?
After one or two days you get access.
And then you can search through the interviews by categories like in this case.
For example, I selected Jewish survivors in a number of languages and at the same time did a full text search for balloon.
So I found 28 interviews of people were talking about balloon and you can jump directly.
You can see directly how many.
Segments of the interviews are being.
The people are talking about this search word and then you can jump directly.
To this spot.
You have revolving subtitles in the original language and in German.
Under the video you have metadata and.
You have like a table of contents with clickable chapters, helping you to understand the complex narrative structure of these biographical interviews.
You can save your searches and take interviews in your personal workbook, so that's a bit of a research environment.
Starting here we, we geocoded the camps and factories and birth places of the narrators.
So you get the European dimension and then you can zoom.
In and you see, for example, the prison in Venice, where this lady talks about where she was brought to.
So this is of course in the educational context quite helpful to see if it's something standing there today and etc.
Um?

We created some additional learning environments.
School also, which I skipped.

This new online archive.
About the German occupation of Greece.
Um, I'll just.
Touch briefly on a future.
Ideas and questions which I would direct to the the declaring colleagues, which would be interesting for us, of course.
Progress in automatic speech recognition in forced alignment.

We did this existing collections manually, which is very expensive and we found that the recording quality, dialect etc is not that good that currently this speech recognition works well, but there is progress being made together with colleagues from Claire in Munich and others.

And then for the future further analysis, it would be helpful to to join forces with linguist methods, historical historiographical questions using corpus linguistics, conversation analysis and of course also taking the audio and the video a bit more.
Ernest, in in our approach.
So one thing, for example that would be interesting for historian is to analyze and compare national or gender specific patterns of Remembrance.
So you could search for word like Sabotage and you would expect women and men talking differently about that or people in former communist countries differently from Western Europe.
So one could search that.
But then of course, search through the translation and then go to the original language an.
You have a lot of problems there, but this is an interesting exam.

Ample it gets more complicated if we try to search of a different collections, because all even the collection that we have in our institution have different fundas, different transfer, transcription guidelines, different metadata, etc.
So it's not easy to make across collection search.
I tried that just with this one person survivor of Auschwitz orchestra and later founder of the British Chamber Orchestra Anita.
Oscar Walfish and two different interviews, 1998 and 2006.
She roughly, of course, talk the same experiences her same life story, but there was a different interviewer, so I looked at the differences between the two interviews.
Ann, just?
I mean, this is a very small start.
I found that in both one minute that in both interviews the interviewer interrupted roughly once a minute, but the way they interrupted was very different.
One interview was a journalist and he should ask a lot of questions, what, where, when, etc.
And the other just made small teams and remarks to support the continuation of the interview.
Depending on the background of the interviewer, depending on the project and the guidelines of the project etc.
So you could analyze much more about how these interviews start to exist in the 1st.
Place.
And of course, formally, oral historians usually worked with the transcript.

Now it's possible to work much more on the gestures and the mimics on the silence is on the brakes, and this is something we would want to engage further also with help of maybe some of the tools that we are learning during this conference.
Thank you very much.
